name: Borgarnes
description: Borgarnes is a historic coastal town of approximately 2,000 residents situated on a peninsula jutting into Borgarfjörður bay in West Iceland, approximately 70 kilometers north of Reykjavík along Ring Road (Route 1). As the largest settlement in the Borgarfjörður region, the town serves as an important service center and gateway to West Iceland's attractions. Borgarnes holds profound significance in Icelandic history as the settlement location of Skallagrímur Kveldúlfsson, father of the legendary Viking poet and warrior Egill Skallagrímsson, one of the most famous figures in Icelandic saga literature. The town's name derives from Borg, Skallagrímur's farm, and nes meaning "peninsula." The Settlement Center (Landnámssetur Íslands), housed in an imaginatively restored harbor warehouse, stands as Borgarnes's premier cultural attraction and one of Iceland's finest historical museums. This award-winning institution features two comprehensive exhibitions, each requiring approximately 30 minutes to explore. The Settlement Exhibition chronicles the discovery and settlement of Iceland from 870 AD onwards, presenting the extraordinary journey of Norse explorers who crossed the North Atlantic to establish permanent communities on this volcanic island. Using multimedia presentations, artifacts, and engaging audioguide narratives available in 15 languages including English, the exhibition brings to life the challenges, motivations, and achievements of Iceland's first settlers.
